The Broadcasting (Independent Productions) Regulations 2025
The Power to Award Degrees etc. (Blackpool and The Fylde College) Order 2025
The Milton Keynes (Electoral Changes) Order 2025
The Cory Decarbonisation Project Order 2025

The Parole Board (Amendment) Rules 2025
The Marine Recovery Funds Regulations 2025
The Civil Procedure (Amendment No. 3) Rules 2025
The Biocidal Products (Data Protection Periods) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These new rules extend by five years—until 31 December 2030—the period during which companies developing new biocidal products (like disinfectants, pesticides, or preservatives) keep exclusive rights to their safety data. This means competitors cannot legally use that data to copy and sell similar products before 2030, protecting the original developer's investment while regulators complete safety reviews for certain substances. It gives businesses clearer security to innovate and maintain market exclusivity for key products affecting public health and environmental safety.

title: The Borough Council of Calderdale (Elland Station and West Vale Access Package) (West Yorkshire Plus Transport Fund, Transforming Cities Fund) (Calder and Hebble Navigation Bridge) Scheme 2022 Confirmation Instrument 2025
The Broadcasting (Regional Programme-making and Original Productions) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: New rules let TV channels (ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5, and S4C) count repeat broadcasts of regional programmes toward their legal requirement to show locally made content. OFCOM must now decide exactly when repeats qualify. This change gives broadcasters flexibility to meet regional content targets using existing shows, potentially reducing pressure to commission entirely new local productions while keeping regional stories on screen. For S4C, the law also updates references to clearly name it as the Welsh-language broadcaster responsible for meeting these rules.

title: The Environmental Protection (Wet Wipes Containing Plastic) (England) Regulations 2025
summary: England now bans shops from selling plastic-containing wet wipes to the public to stop them clogging drains and polluting rivers. You can't buy these wipes in stores, but pharmacies can still supply them for medical needs, and businesses or councils can order them for professional use. Fines and forced shutdowns will hit shops breaking the rule, with enforcers inspecting premises and publishing violations. This means fewer plastic wipes ending up in sewers and waterways, protecting local environments and reducing clean-up costs for communities.

title: The Portsmouth International Port and Camber Harbour Revision Order 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Pontyclun) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Hall Farm, Langford, Newark) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (Commencement No. 6, 8 and 9 and Saving Provisions) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: Extends domestic abuse protection orders in England and Wales pilot areas until 31 March 2026, giving victims four extra months of immediate safety from abusers. Ensures courts can still issue or appeal these orders if applications were made before the original November 2025 pilot end date, even if decisions are pending. Police and courts keep using these tools to urgently separate victims from perpetrators without gaps in legal coverage.

title: The Football Governance Act 2025 (Specified Competitions) Regulations 2025
The National Health Service (Procurement, Slavery and Human Trafficking) Regulations 2025
summary: Hospitals and other health service buyers in England must now check for signs of modern slavery or human trafficking in every supplier they use—from medical equipment to cleaning services. If they find risks, they must fix the problems immediately and keep checking over time. This forces the healthcare system to actively hunt out and stop exploitation in its supply chains, protecting vulnerable workers and ensuring public funds don’t support slave labour. NHS England will set clear rules for how these checks happen, making ethical sourcing mandatory across the health service.

title: The Occupational Pensions (Revaluation) Order 2025
The Procurement Act 2023 (Threshold Amounts) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 (Commencement No. 4) Regulations 2025
The Extradition Act 2003 (Amendment to Designations) Order 2025
The Clean Heat Market Mechanism (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Sentencing Act 2020 (Special Procedures for Community and Suspended Sentence Orders) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: The law now lets courts apply special sentencing rules—like community orders or suspended sentences—to eligible cases until March 2029 instead of December 2025. This gives judges more time to use alternatives to jail for these cases, extending a probation or rehabilitation-focused system for nearly four additional years and reducing pressure on prisons while supporting community-based accountability.

title: The Online Safety Act 2023 (Fees) (Threshold Figure) Regulations 2025
The Merchant Shipping (Vessels in Commercial Use for Sport or Pleasure) Regulations 2025
The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities) (Amendment) Order 2025
The Crediting of Third Country and Military Certification for Air Traffic Controllers Regulations 2025
The European Registers of Road Transport Undertakings (Disclosure of Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Electricity (Individual Exemption from the Requirement for a Transmission Licence) (Dogger Bank A) (Amendment) Order 2025
The Private International Law (Implementation of Agreements) Act 2020 (Extension of Operative Period) Regulations 2025
The Power to Award Degrees etc. (S P Jain London School of Management Limited) (Amendment) Order 2025
The Social Security (Residence in an EEA State or Switzerland) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These regulations ensure people who were already receiving disability or carer benefits under EU rules before the UK left the EU can continue getting those payments. To qualify, they must have lived outside the UK since December 31, 2020, and remained on the benefits without interruption. This change preserves existing support for vulnerable groups affected by Brexit but does not open new claims. Those currently receiving Carer’s Allowance, Disability Living Allowance (care component), or Personal Independence Payment (daily living component) who moved abroad won’t lose their benefits immediately, maintaining financial stability for thousands.

title: The Trade Act 2021 (Power to Implement International Trade Agreements) (Extension to Expiry) Regulations 2025
The Customs Tariff (Establishment) (EU Exit) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Export Control (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Charities Act 2022 (Commencement No. 4 and Saving Provision) Regulations 2025
summary: The 2025 regulations introduce a streamlined process for charities to make small payments driven by moral obligations—without needing prior approval from regulators or courts—as long as they meet clear legal tests. From November 2025, charity trustees can approve these payments directly, with the maximum amount tied to the charity’s annual income (making larger charities more flexible). A separate change clarifies that decisions on such payments can be handled by others, not just trustees, though trustees remain accountable. Museums and galleries remain barred from removing certain collection items, preserving existing safeguards. These changes aim to reduce bureaucracy while ensuring responsible financial use, potentially speeding up support for vulnerable individuals or public services in urgent need.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Windsor) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Education (Inspectors of Education and Training in Wales) Order 2025
summary: This law names specific individuals as official overseers responsible for monitoring education and training standards in Wales, enabling them to ensure quality and accountability across schools, colleges, and vocational programs. Their role includes identifying gaps in compliance, driving improvements, and reporting findings to support better outcomes for learners and educators.

title: The Control of Mercury (Enforcement) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: The UK’s mercury regulations now bar importing and exporting dental amalgam, with customs officers empowered to enforce these restrictions. It also adds new EU mercury controls—covering products like dental fillings—to the list of enforceable rules, tightening oversight of mercury use to protect human health and the environment. No major business costs are anticipated.

title: The Senedd Cymru (Disqualification) Order 2025 / Gorchymyn Senedd Cymru (Anghymhwyso) 2025
summary: This law changes which jobs prevent someone from becoming a member of the Welsh Parliament (Senedd Cymru) starting in elections held on or after April 6, 2026. People holding certain offices listed in the Schedule (like specific public roles) will no longer be allowed to serve as elected members, though they can still run as candidates. It replaces previous rules from 2020, which will only apply to elections before April 2026. The change aims to separate elected roles from other positions to ensure independence in Parliament.

title: The Financial Services (Gibraltar) (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2025
summary: The UK has extended for one more year a temporary agreement allowing Gibraltar-based financial firms to continue serving UK customers and enabling UK firms to operate in Gibraltar's market. This gives both sides more time to adjust to post-Brexit rules without disrupting existing services or requiring immediate compliance changes. No major economic effects are expected, but details on the minimal impact are available for transparency.

title: The Civil Enforcement of Parking Contraventions (County of East Sussex) (Amendment), Bus Lane Contraventions (Approved Local Authorities) (Amendment) and Moving Traffic Contraventions Designation Order 2025
